docs.lead_paragraph: New York is helping to lead states in a nationwide effort to persuade the federal government to provide billions of dollars in additional aid to help the states cover the cost of Medicaid, the health insurance program for the poor. The nation's governors are predicting that because of the slumping economy, at least four million more people will go on the Medicaid rolls in the next six months, even as states face budget shortfalls that are forcing them to reduce other services.

headline.main: States Calling For More Help With Medicaid

docs.lead_paragraph: When Charles Lewellen reported for his weekend rotation at the Naval Reserve Center in the Bronx last month, he checked to see if he had made adequate preparations in case he was called up for active duty. His finances? Check. His physical and mental health? Check, check. His life insurance, will and paperwork? Check, check and check. Everything, in fact, seemed to be in order except for one potential dealbreaker: He had four teeth that needed new fillings and two with bad root canals that needed to be extracted.

headline.main: Mentally, They're Fine. Dentally, Not Always.

docs.abstract: US military reservists called to active duty are having teeth checked at training centers by dentists who are finding many in urgent need of treatment; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: As Senate and House negotiators meet this week to reconcile their appropriations bills for Labor and Health and Human Services, one key issue they will have to address is whether to outlaw disparities between insurance coverage for mental and physical illnesses. The Senate bill would rightly do so, but House leaders are being lobbied by the health care industry to refrain from doing the same. The stigma surrounding mental illness is lifting as it becomes increasingly apparent that millions of Americans who suffer from afflictions ranging from schizophrenia to depression can obtain treatment that allows them to lead full lives. The Senate's bipartisan measure, co-sponsored by 66 members, would force insurance companies to cover mental disorders on the same terms as they would physical ailments. It would prevent large employers' health plans from setting higher deductibles and co-payments for patients treated for mental disorders than for those treated for illnesses like cancer or respiratory problems.
docs.abstract: Editorial urges Pres Bush to direct House Republican leaders to embrace Senate bill that would rightly outlaw disparities between insurance coverage for mental and physical illnesses (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: PRUDENTIAL INSURANCE, one of the best-known names in life insurance, plans to sell 110 million shares this week in the biggest initial public offering since the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks. But because the market for new issues remains unsettled, and because Prudential's profits compare unfavorably with those of its competitors, many analysts expect the company to set a modest price for the shares, perhaps $27.50 each on Wednesday. That would be about 85 percent of Prudential's book value, while its rival for leadership in the American life insurance business, MetLife, is trading at 1.4 times book value. The comparable multiple for John Hancock, another major insurer, is 2.14.

headline.main: Investing; Prudential Is Set to Take the Plunge

docs.abstract: Prudential Insurance Co of America, now Prudential Financial, plans to sell 110 million shares in biggest initial public offering since Sept 11 terrorist attacks; modest price is expected for offering in view of unsettled market for new stock issues and fact that company's earnings compare unfavorably with those of its competitors; analysts sill say Prudential has considerable appeal; photo; table (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: The ''cost-saving'' measure for health insurance (front page, Dec. 5) will drive the horrific 70 percent unemployment rate for people with disabilities even higher. As an employed person with a disability, I and my family would be punished for my extra medical expenses. Most of these are for preventive care that enables me to keep healthy and working.

headline.main: A Health Maze: Which Way Out?

docs.lead_paragraph: Detroit's mayor has scrapped his offer of a raise to 17,000 municipal workers, saying the city can no longer afford pay increases. In Middletown, N.J., a judge jailed more than 200 teachers who went on strike after the school board insisted that they pay more for health insurance. And United Airlines has told 15,000 members of the machinists' union, who are angry about not receiving a raise since 1994, that the company might not be able to give them a raise this year either because it is losing so much money.

headline.main: Labor Runs Into Hard Times As It Negotiates for Raises

docs.abstract: AFL-CIO convention in Las Vegas comes at time when it is becoming harder for union members to win wage increases through collective bargaining; reasons include war against terrorism, recession, rising unemployment, soaring health care costs and slumps in many industries, notably airlines (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Re ''A New Health Plan May Raise Expenses for Sickest Workers'' (front page, Dec. 5): In a quiet move ominously reminiscent of the rise of ''managed'' health care, the insurance industry is introducing a plan that will further erode patient choice, discriminate against the sick and require large administrative costs.

headline.main: A Health Maze: Which Way Out?

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Re ''A New Health Plan May Raise Expenses for Sickest Workers'' (front page, Dec. 5): Employers and insurers will not only be shifting costs to sick people, they will also make it harder for working families to get basic preventive care. The way these plans work, a family will be receiving an allowance each year to spend on medical expenses. Families will be forced to ration care by choosing to spend their allocation on meeting the health care needs of one family member at the expense of other family members who may have to forgo care.

headline.main: A Health Maze: Which Way Out?

docs.lead_paragraph: WITH the holiday season already muted in this Monmouth County suburb, the last thing township residents needed or wanted was the mass arrest of its striking teachers like so many Taliban soldiers. Yet by late last week, about 150 striking school employees -- protesting increased teacher payments for health insurance benefits -- were led in handcuffs to the county jail.

headline.main: Jail, Not Classes, Is Crowded In Middletown

docs.abstract: Article on mass arrest in Middletown, NJ, of teachers striking against increased payments for health insurance benefits; community is already reeling from layoffs at Lucent Technologies and loss of 34 residents in World Trade Center attack; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: ''A New Health Plan May Raise Expenses for Sickest Workers'' (front page, Dec. 5) did not mention that consumers are demanding more choice and flexibility in how they use their health benefits. Products that provide consumers with additional choices in how and when to spend their health care dollars can include features like first dollar coverage for preventive care to encourage employees to access care.

headline.main: A Health Maze: Which Way Out?
